column1: Unlike eg divi the pagebuilder is a REAL pagebuilder and will not let you down on stuff like woocommerce or expects you to install yet another 5 third party plugins.

However a little downside. The archive/posts/blog widgets aren’t very good if you’re used to theming yourself – alone the inability of adding the category in the meta of the blogteasers (when using the classical format) is almost shamefull. The whole customization of the achieve posts overview is very limited and basically lets you choose between two layouts that can be customized only in a minor way. Since there are so many other widgets with so many more customization options, I don’t think it might be *that* difficult to add these for the posts (obviously I’m not the developer so I might be wrong, it’s just seems weird)? Also the pagination is flawed – not only that pagination for archive looks completely different from the pagination only widget, the lack of category.php and index.php style templates will make you browse through every site with the pagination, instead of the respective category or tag or such.
I really hope that there will be category/index templates in the future, and I think this is a way more useful feature than stuff like the recently added pop up builder.
As long as there isnt’ I guess I will have to continue coding blogs myself üòâ

Another point that bugs me, is that i have to put additional css into the wp customization, instead of being able to use my theme/a child theme, as their css files are completely ignored. Not being able to set up something essential like the link-colours in my own css (unless I couldn’t find some documentation on it in my hours of research) is really annoying. Ofc it can be done via wp customizer, but i prefer to have stuff like this in my own css.
Last but not least I feel like it produces too much markup, which is common for page builders, and here again, i might not have enough insight.

Don’t get me wrong, this review might sound overall pretty negative and it really isn’t. I just hope it gets read and the developers take these suggestions into account while continuing an overall very good and powerful plugin, that makes my life a lot easier.

column5: As someone who enjoys web design, I really appreciate the power and flexibility given by page builders. I’ve tried a lot of them in the past, and saw Elementor when it first came out. It was as good as the promo video made it out to be.

column1: + Excellent for both old-time web designers and beginners

I may enjoy HTML and CSS but the rate at which I create design drafts is astonishingly fast with this particular page builder. You can still do your own HTML if you want to, it’s just faster to use the blocks and widgets given. The learning curve is less steep than most other page builders of this kind, if you’re not sure which one to get, it’s should probably be this one.
+ A lot of things for no cost

They do have a pro version now but I haven’t personally tried it myself. I’m satisfied with what the free version could do, as I could just manually code things out if its few limitations end up hindering my design drafts. Compare this to other page builders for the same price range of free, it’s really no debate.
– Some technical issues here and there

It does occasionally bug out and I end up losing some work. Sometimes the styles fail to load and I have to figure out what’s causing it. And for some reason it has an issue with Cloudflare’s Rocket Loader, which will end up destroying your design and won’t allow you to edit the page at all.
There was one time I had to rollback to a previous version because the latest version I was using ended up ruining all of my pages. It’s not like I was using an incompatible plugin alongside it.
– Background images and mixed content warnings after site migration with SSL

To put it simply, I finish my designs and polish the functionality and prepare for a site migration. After successfully setting the configs and the database, the site runs smoothly and the designs are fine. Problem is there are mixed content warnings on my site.

What’s causing it? The content sections, even after correcting the background image URLs, both from the site itself via Elementor and the database, still request from the previous URL. In this case, it was requesting for images from the localhost directory. The fix is simple, remove those content sections entirely, then redo them.

Aside from these flaws, which some of them are quite annoying and probably major to some web designers, it’s a solid tool. You should definitely give it a shot. Just keep these cons in mind as they will pester you during development or server migrations.
